div.head: Question 51

head.supplied: Whether the teaching of the venerable Anselm rationally ought to be condemned?

div.p: Whether the teaching of the Venerable Anselm rationally ought to be condemned?

That yes, it is argued because it is erroneous, as is clear in
8 book of On the free will , where he teaches that God is not able to remove the rectitude of the will from the will, and nevertheless he holds that this something different from the will, which is erroneous because God is able to separate everything that is totally distinct from something else, therefore etc.
It is said that it is distinguished from the will

Against, therefore either it is effectively from the will or not. If thus, contra, it is not in the power of the will to cause rectitude in itself but to preserve, as he says. Again affections are created by God,
de concordia, capitulo 17
therefore etc.

Similarly, if it causes rectitude, it does so either by willing or not willing. If by willing, and no one wishes rectitude unless having rectitude, it has before what it causes, and this is the argument of the same one in
De concordia, chapter 13 .

If rectitude is not effective from the will, then it should not be thought of us a free will, which is in opposition to
Augustine, in the first book of the Retractions, chapter 9 .
It is said that it depends on the will with respect to conservation, not with respect to production.

Against this, it is in the power of sinners to produce contrition, and every contrition is rectitude of the will, therefore etc. This is confirmed because the rectitude of the will is to will what God wills it to will,
On free will, chapter 8 , but this kind of willing is effectively from the will, therefore etc.
Again, everything which man has if he wishes to have it and does not have it unless he wishes to have, he has from the will, as is seen. Rectitude belongs to this class of things, etc.

Again, in
II Cur Deus homo, chapter 14 , he puts five propositions. The first is that to act against the will of God even what we think the lightest moral sin is of so great a weight that it is not able to happen that there is salvation in an infinity of worlds.
But against this, then any sin is of infinite badness in intention because if of finite badness, then the salvation of some worlds will it be so good, just as this will be bad.
Second proposition, that the smallest injury of Christ is a greater evil than all sins outside the person of Christ.
Against, then the killing of Christ would not have been a greater evil than the small injury of Christ.
Third, the life of Christ was of greater good than all sins are bad.

Against, then he was a greater good than his murder. The consequent against him because
every good is as good as as its destruction is bad
Anselm Cur Deus Homo II, c. 14
,
II Cur Deus homo, chapter 14 , and it was as bad to kill him as his life was good.

Again, the life of Christ was sufficient satisfaction for sin, therefore he was an infinite good. The consequence is proved through what is said in
I Cur Deus homo, chapter 21 ,
you will never satisfy unless you pay back something greater than that for which sin you ought not to have done
Anselm, Cur Deus Homo, I, c. 21
. But man ought not to sin for any finite good, as the first proposition says, therefore, etc.

Fourth proposition,
every good is as good as its destruction is bad

Against, God instructs Socrates that he should not destroy this straw under penalty of mortal sin and that he should not kill a lion under penalty of venial sin, and acts against each, then the straw is of greater goodness that the lion because its destruction is worse.
Fifth, the life of the body of Christ is more loveable than all sins are hatable.
Against, the amount of the first that is loveable, is equal because, by loving God one hates sin, and by hating sin, one loves God.

Again, if this were so and it were the case that no one ought to have loved him more than he loved himself, therefore this one ought to have loved him more than he hated sin, therefore he ought not to have given this live for the satisfaction of sin.

Again,
Proslogion, chapter 25 .

Again, he says about the Blessed Virgin that
she was conceived and born in original sin
Anselm Cur Deus homo II, c. 16
,
II, Cur Deus homo, chapter 16 .

Again, he proves that God is not able to destroy the rectitude of the will because this is either by willing or not willing. Not by not willing as is clear. Not by willing because if this is the case, then he wishes that he does it, and from whose will he wishes to withdraw the rectitude, he does not wish that keeps the rectitude. But to keep the rectitude is will just as God will it to will, therefore if God destroys the rectitude from the will, he does not will that it will what he wishes it to will.

But against this because the devil wishes just God wishes him to will because knows that this consequence is valid, the devil is obstinate in evil, therefore he wishes unjustly, and God wishes the antecedent and that the consequence is valid, therefore it follows that he wills the consequent.

Again, if no will will be
correct unless it will just as God wishes it to will, it follows that in Christ there was some non-correct will when he said in
Matthew 26
not as I will, but as you will
, etc.

Again, against this form of arguing Anselmi he argues thus, because when God removes grace, either he wishes one not to have grace or he does not wish. If he wishes him not, therefore etc., for then he is not a debtor of grace. Against, he commands him always to have grace. If he wishes that he has grace, then he does not remove it.

Therefore to this proposition about the rectitude of the will, I say that he understands that God is not able to separate it from the will having grace "ipsa invita" for his ordained power. And thus is the end of the question.
